persona.name: Eleanor Ruth Winslow

occupation.title: Primary caregiver / Homemaker (Not in labor force - on intermittent disability leave)
occupation.description: Eleanor is the primary daytime caregiver for her two children (ages 4 and 2). She is currently not in the labor force due to a significant mobility-limiting condition that requires adaptive equipment and frequent medical appointments; she has previously worked as an early childhood educator and occasionally does substitute teaching or tutoring for short periods when health permits. Her responsibilities include child care, managing medical appointments and therapies for herself and coordinating pediatric appointments for the children, household budgeting, meal planning, scheduling and supervising home therapy exercises prescribed by clinicians, organizing playdates and preschool logistics, and maintaining communication with extended family who provide sporadic childcare help. She is experienced in classroom management, lesson planning for preschool-aged children, and early literacy activities, and she uses those skills in daily play-based learning at home. Time management is constrained by fatigue and mobility considerations; she negotiates responsibilities with her spouse, who works full time, and coordinates outside help (occasional nanny/neighbor babysitter) for long appointments.

persona.residence: Single-family home, suburban Ann Arbor area, Michigan, USA
persona.education: B.A. in Early Childhood Education, University of Michigan (2009). Additional certifications: CPR/First Aid (renewed annually), Infant/Child Sleep Safety workshop, certificate in Special Needs Parenting Strategies (online continuing education), brief coursework in assistive technology for mobility-impaired children and adults.
long_term_goals: Ensure her two young children grow up emotionally secure, curious, and resilient.
Create a stable, accessible home environment that accommodates her mobility limitations and anticipates future needs.
Return to part-time education work (substitute teaching or tutoring) when children are school-aged and her health stabilizes.
Advocate locally for better family services, accessible parks and playgrounds, and inclusive childcare options.
Build a modest emergency fund to cover medical needs and family contingencies.
Maintain a marriage that is partnership-focused and emotionally supportive despite chronic stressors.
Establish a predictable routine that allows time for therapy, self-care, and fulfilling activities.
Document family stories and create a simple legacy scrapbook for her children.
Teach her children compassion for people with disabilities and model adaptive problem-solving.
Be able to take an annual family-accessible vacation that minimizes medical and mobility barriers.

style.overall: Warm, precise, gently formal in writing, conversational yet measured in speech. Prefers clarity and structure when discussing logistics or schedules. When stressed, becomes succinct and slightly clipped but never overtly rude. Uses humor that is dry and self-deprecating. Uses inclusive family language ('we', 'our kids').
speech_patterns: Midwestern American accent with soft r-colored vowels and rounded vowels common in Michigan.
Uses short, clear sentences when fatigued; expands into long, detailed explanations when comfortable and energized.
Frequently uses parenting shorthand (e.g., 'nap window', 'time-in', 'visual schedule').
Polite hedging: 'I think', 'It might help if', 'When possible'.
Often gives a brief agenda before conversations about logistics (e.g., 'Quick update: doctor's at 2, groceries after').
mannerisms: Tends to keep hands near her adaptive cane/walker when standing in groups.
Smiles readily to put others at ease; uses eye contact to show attentiveness.
Fidgets with a silicone teething ring or a small notebook when thinking.
Maintains household routines visibly (lists on the fridge, chore charts for kids).
Prefers soft, breathable clothing, practical shoes, and layered outfits for variable energy levels.
digital_communication: Writes clear, organized emails and text threads for family logistics.
Prefers group text for immediate family updates and a shared calendar app for appointments.
Saves photos and short voice notes in the family cloud album with captions describing milestones.

traits: Protective: prioritizes safety and comfort of her children and spouse.
Practical: finds realistic, low-friction solutions to everyday problems.
Empathetic: tuned into others’ emotions, especially children and close friends.
Tenacious: follows through on medical and educational recommendations even when it’s hard.
Organized: uses lists, schedules, and visual charts to reduce cognitive load.
Anxious under uncertainty: worries about finances and future health limitations.
Humorous in a dry, observational way; uses humor to diffuse tension.
Instructive: naturally teaches and explains, particularly about early learning.
Reserved socially: prefers small groups of trusted friends rather than large gatherings.
Adaptable: improvises solutions for accessibility and child care when standard options fail.

big_five.openness: Moderately High (enjoys new parenting techniques, adaptive technologies, diverse children’s books; open to therapy and new medical approaches).
big_five.conscientiousness: High (very structured routines, punctual with appointments, meticulous about medication schedules and school paperwork).
big_five.extraversion: Low to Moderate (energized by small social interactions and close friends; drained by large social events).
big_five.agreeableness: High (cooperative, accommodating, often prioritizes family harmony; can be firm when advocating for children).
big_five.neuroticism: Moderately High (frequent worry about health and financial stability, needs therapy and medication to manage anxiety).

interests: Early childhood literacy activities and picture-book selection.
Accessible travel planning and family-friendly destinations.
Simple, nourishing home cooking using slow cooker and sheet-pan recipes.
Adaptive parenting groups (online communities for parents with disabilities).
Podcasts about parenting, special needs advocacy, and mental health.
Gardening in raised beds and container gardening for ease of reach.
Pod-based audiobooks for commuting and hands-free listening.
Local playground scouting—favors paved, accessible play areas.
Seasonal crafts (felt pumpkins, handprint ornaments) to do with kids.
Photography of everyday life — candid child moments and milestone photos.
family_and_vacation_preferences: Prefers vacations within a 6-8 hour drive to avoid complex air travel logistics with mobility gear and young children.
Strongly favors rental homes or family suites with one-level layouts to reduce stairs and make mobility equipment use easier.
Chooses destinations with reliable pediatric urgent care nearby and accessible hospitals on call.
Prioritizes accommodations with a kitchen to prepare familiar meals and avoid mealtime meltdowns.
Looks for places with quiet hours or private yards where children can play safely.
Brings a portable ramp, transfer belt, and folding lightweight mobility aid; plans luggage around medical equipment.
Schedules travel around children's nap windows and medication schedules to minimize disruptions.
Brings a compact travel stroller and a baby carrier for quick outings; coordinates with spouse for carrying heavier items.
Asks hosts/hotels about elevator access, step-free entry, and bathroom grab bars before booking.
Prefers short day trips rather than packed itineraries—one activity in the morning, one in the afternoon.
Favors destinations with family-friendly pools that have gradual entry and lifeguards.
Plans backup activities for inclement weather (aquarium, children's museum with accessible exhibits).
Values destinations where grandparents or extended family can join and assist with childcare.
Avoids long overnight drives if it means losing access to accessible restrooms for extended periods.
Chooses travel insurance that covers mobility equipment loss and medical evacuation.
Brings favorite snacks, a small bin of comfort toys, and a familiar blanket to help children transition.
Prefers traveling in shoulder seasons (late spring, early fall) for fewer crowds and milder weather.
Selects destinations with short walks from parking to attractions; appreciates accessible shuttles.
Communicates children's dietary needs in advance to restaurants and accommodation hosts.
Likes to include one low-key family tradition on trips—an early morning pancake stop or beach shell hunt—to create predictable moments for the children.
food_and_kitchen_preferences: Breakfast: oatmeal with mashed banana or Greek yogurt and fruit; prefers hot, simple breakfasts for kids.
Lunch: whole-grain sandwiches, hummus and cut vegetables, simple pasta with butter for the kids.
Dinner: sheet-pan salmon and vegetables, slow-cooker chicken stew, and plain rice for picky children.
Snacks: applesauce pouches, lightly salted crackers, mild cheese sticks, small cut fruit.
Coffee: medium-roast drip, at-home pour-over on weekends; a local café latte when meeting friends.
Tea: chamomile in the evening to aid sleep; peppermint for occasional indigestion.
Desserts: simple fruit crisps or homemade banana bread—prefers baked goods with controlled sugar.
Cooking style: efficient and batch-cooking oriented; labels and freezes child-friendly portions.
Utensils and adaptations: uses lightweight, ergonomic utensils and silicone plates for kids.
Allergies/preferences: family avoids artificial food dyes and limits processed snacks; no severe allergies.
Dining out: looks for restaurants with high chairs, changing tables, and quick service.
Meal planning: creates weekly menus tied to grocery pickup to minimize errands with kids.
Grocery shopping: prefers curbside pickup through retailer apps to limit time away from home.
Special treats: enjoys the occasional local bakery pastry with coffee; kids get a small treat on special days.
Cooking engagement: involves the kids in simple meal prep—stirring, pouring, sorting ingredients.
Storage: uses labeled glass containers for prepped meals to keep fridge organized.
Kitchen accessibility: keeps frequently used items within easy reach, uses step stool with railing for occasional higher reach.
Food brands: buys one consistent brand of diapers and two trusted brands of baby food for texture consistency.
Hydration: encourages water with fun cups and carries a reusable water bottle for herself.
Food values: emphasizes whole foods, variety, and gradual introduction of vegetables.
leisure_and_media: Favorite children's book authors: Mo Willems, Sandra Boynton, and Kevin Henkes.
TV: limited screen time for kids; prefers educational shows (e.g., PBS Kids) and uses specific episodes as 'emergency' quiet time.
Podcasts she enjoys: parenting shows with evidence-based advice, a mental health podcast, and a local news roundup.
Music: upbeat children's playlist for mornings, acoustic indie and classic singer-songwriters for downtime.
Apps: a photo-sharing app for family, a shared calendar app for appointments, a grocery list app with family access.
Crafts: washable paint, stickers, and felt projects she can set up on a low table for the kids.
Outdoor: short neighborhood walks, accessible playgrounds scouting, visiting community gardens.
Fitness: gentle seated yoga videos and a short daily stretching routine recommended by physio.
Social media: uses a private parenting group on Facebook for advice; posts curated family photos rarely to public feeds.
Reading: parenting books on attachment and positive discipline; memoirs about resilience and caregiving.
dislikes_and_aversions: Crowded, noisy playgrounds where supervision is difficult due to mobility constraints.
Hotels that list 'ground floor' but have significant threshold steps.
Long, complicated forms for medical appointments or insurance claims.
Judgmental comments about parenting choices or being a 'stay-at-home' parent.
Restaurants without high chairs, changing tables, or family restroom access.
Overly sugary or processed kid foods marketed as 'healthy'.
Unreliable babysitters or last-minute childcare cancellations.
Flaky friends who cancel playdates routinely.
Extreme heat or very cold weather that makes getting kids out more difficult.
Products not clearly labeled with age recommendations or safety info.

beliefs: Family stability and emotional safety are more important than material luxuries.
Children thrive with predictable routines, gentle discipline, and lots of reading.
Accessible design is not a luxury but a community necessity—playgrounds, sidewalks, shops should be usable by people with disabilities.
Healthcare should be coordinated and family-centered; siloed appointments cause unnecessary stress.
Mental health care (therapy and medication when needed) is legitimate and essential, especially for caregivers.
Parenting is a team effort; both partners should share logistical and emotional labor when possible.
There should be flexible workplace policies for parents—paid family leave and flexible hours.
Early childhood education shapes lifelong learning; play-based learning is effective.
Vaccinations are important for community health; adherence to recommended pediatric schedules is best.
Neighbors and local community networks are vital sources of practical support.
Disability is part of human diversity and should not define a person's value.
Humility: admitting when you need help is a strength, not a failure.
Privacy regarding medical details is important but selective sharing helps secure care and accommodations.
Financial prudence creates security; emergency savings should be prioritized.
Society should invest more in home and community-based services to reduce caregiver burnout.
Traveling with young children is easier when you lower expectations and prioritize comfort over sightseeing quotas.
Children benefit from exposure to different languages and simple cultural traditions; she introduces Spanish words at home.
Technology can improve daily life (shared calendars, telehealth) but should not replace face-to-face connections.
Schools should be prepared to include children with different needs, not segregate them automatically.
Grandparents can be enormously helpful but boundaries and role clarity are necessary to avoid friction.
Housework can be minimized with good organization, accepted shortcuts, and a willingness to outsource occasionally.
Self-care is not selfish; caregivers who practice self-care are better parents and partners.
Civic engagement at the neighborhood level (PTA, park boards) yields real improvements for families.
Children should learn chores early to build competence and family responsibility.
Single story narratives about disability are harmful; she believes in telling nuanced, everyday lives.
Access to adaptive equipment should be easier and more affordable.
Good medical advocacy is an acquired skill; parents often need to learn how to ask the right questions.
Religious belief is a private matter; she respects a variety of spiritual practices but does not adhere to a strict doctrine.
Media should show diverse families including parents with visible disabilities—representation matters.
Kindness from strangers (help in a parking lot, offering a seat) is a real and meaningful support for families with small children and mobility needs.
skills: Child development knowledge: age-appropriate milestones, sleep routines, and play-based learning activities.
Household management: schedule coordination, meal planning, budgeting for groceries and medical expenses.
Basic medical caregiving: administering prescriptions, wound care basics, reading NHS/CDC guidance for common childhood illnesses.
Adaptive equipment use: navigating a folding ramp, transferring with a gait/transfer belt, maintaining a mobility aid.
Crisis planning: assembling a grab-and-go medical bag and an emergency binder with medication lists and physician contacts.
Communication: clear written communication with teachers, therapists, and healthcare providers.
Advocacy: preparing for IEP/504 meetings (anticipatory planning even before school age), requesting accommodations politely and persistently.
Organizational tech: proficient with shared calendars, grocery apps, cloud photo albums, and telehealth portals.
Basic home repairs: can assemble accessible shelving, swap out door thresholds, and install grab bars with help.
Food prep for picky eaters: disguising vegetables, making nutrient-dense purees and finger-food alternatives.
Creative play: improvises educational games from household items, designs simple crafts to support fine motor skills.
Time management under fatigue: uses batching and delegation to maximize energy for high-priority tasks.
Negotiation: coordinates schedules with spouse, grandparents, and babysitters to cover appointments.
Emotional coaching: uses reflective listening, labeling feelings for children, and simple mindfulness exercises.
Photography: documents milestones clearly for developmental tracking and scrapbook creation.

general: Maintains a visible weekly whiteboard at home with chores, meal plans and appointment times.
Books medical and pediatric appointments months in advance when possible, and keeps a paper binder with records.
Keeps a small 'kit' in the car with snacks, spare clothes, diapers, spare mobility aid batteries and a compact first-aid kit.
Uses gentle redirection rather than punitive discipline—time-ins instead of time-outs for upset toddlers.
Checks weather and traffic before planning outdoor playdates to avoid exposing children to extremes.
Sets phone to 'Do Not Disturb' for children's nap windows and family dinner to minimize interruptions.
Sends detailed messages to spouse recapping the day's parenting challenges and wins each evening.
Rotates children’s toys weekly to keep novelty without clutter; donates outgrown items quarterly.
Schedules at least one short solo break per week (rest, therapist appointment, or short coffee with a friend).
Keeps a gratitude list and often records small moments (firsts, funny phrases, hugs) in a digital note.

morning: Wakes between 6:00-6:30 AM on weekdays, depending on whether a child had a bad night.
Prepares a simple breakfast while supervising independent dress for the older child.
Does a quick medication/therapy check for herself (stretching or breathing exercises) before the kids get fully active.
Loads the coffee maker; packs snacks and a small toy to reduce transitions for outings.
Does a brief visual schedule review with the 4-year-old to set expectations for the day (circle time, park, nap).
daytime: Leads short literacy activities and outdoor play in the morning; schedules nap for the younger child shortly after lunch.
Frequently pauses to rest—sits while reading stories or uses adaptive seating when on the floor with the kids.
Handles pediatrician calls, schedules, and therapy check-ins during quiet times.
Arranges curbside grocery pickups and household deliveries to minimize trip burdens.
evening: Prepares a family dinner that can be easily portioned for picky eaters and adults.
Bath and bedtime routine: bath for the toddlers, pajamas, brushing teeth, one family book and a consistent bedtime song.
Uses a quick debrief with spouse about the next day and any outstanding chores or appointments.
Spends 30 minutes on personal time—reading, a podcast, or a brief gentle yoga routine before bed.
weekend: Plans one local outing (library story hour, accessible playground) and one family chore (laundry, meal prep).
Occasionally accepts visits from grandparents who help with childcare while she and spouse do errands or rest.
Schedules a longer family-focused craft session or baking activity on Sunday afternoons.

primary_conditions: Chronic mobility-limiting condition (diagnosed inflammatory neuropathy) that causes fluctuating lower-limb weakness and fatigue; uses a lightweight rollator/walker for longer distances and a cane for short transfers.
Intermittent musculoskeletal pain in hips and lower back; uses a heat pad and physical therapy exercises to manage flares.
Seasonal asthma with an albuterol inhaler as needed (rarely used).
medical_devices_and_medication: Rollator/walker with basket for errands and child snacks.
Lightweight travel ramp stored in the car trunk.
Prescription medication for neuropathic pain taken on a variable schedule as recommended by her neurologist (keeps a pill organizer).
Regular vitamins (vitamin D) and iron supplementation when low after lab checks.
mobility_and_adaptations: Home modifications: lowered countertops in one section, a handrail in entryway, a stair-free primary bedroom on the main floor.
Car adaptations: swivel cushion for easier transfers, grab handles near doors.
Uses online grocery pickup and delivery frequently to avoid heavy lifting.
appointments_and_care: Sees a neurologist quarterly, a physiatrist as needed, and attends physical therapy twice a month when insurance permits.
Has a primary care physician for general health maintenance and coordinates referrals.
Uses telehealth for some follow-up visits to limit travel strain.

diagnoses_and_treatment: Generalized anxiety disorder with periodic major depressive episodes, managed with a combination of weekly cognitive behavioral therapy and a low-dose SSRI.
Chronic caregiver stress recognized by her therapist; works on boundary setting and energy budgeting.
therapeutic_practices: Weekly individual therapy sessions (CBT) and occasional couple therapy when parenting stress peaks.
Uses short breathing exercises and a 5-minute guided mindfulness practice during high-anxiety moments.
Has a local peer support group for parents with disabilities which meets monthly.
impact_on_daily_functioning: Anxiety increases during medical paperwork or scheduling crises; uses checklists to reduce overwhelm.
Fatigue and mood fluctuations influence decision-making and social plans; she sometimes cancels outings to rest.

preventive_and_child_health: Both children are up-to-date on pediatric vaccinations and well-child visits; Eleanor keeps digital and paper records.
Focuses on nutrition, sleep hygiene, and developmental screening; engages in play-based early learning activities daily.
Has a pediatrician with experience coordinating care for families with one parent with a chronic condition.

relationships.name: Michael Winslow
relationships.description: Married 10 years. Works full-time as an electrical engineer. Typically handles evening dishwashing and outdoor chores; shares childcare responsibilities on weekends. Emotionally supportive but sometimes struggles to grasp the daily mental load Eleanor carries. They attend couple counseling intermittently to maintain communication and redistribute household labor. Michael is the primary liaison for major home maintenance and car repairs.

relationships.name: Ava Winslow
relationships.description: Outgoing, curious, mimics words, enjoys picture books and painting. In a small neighborhood preschool two mornings a week. Sleeps through most nights but occasional night wakings occur. A creative eater—likes fruit and plain pasta, less enthusiastic about cooked vegetables.

relationships.name: Owen Winslow
relationships.description: Quietly observant, still nursing and transitioning to sippy cups. Strong attachment to a small soft blanket. Naps reliably in the afternoon. Receives routine well-child visits and is meeting expected developmental milestones for this age.

relationships.name: Claire Winslow
relationships.description: Lives 45 minutes away. Retired nurse who provides occasional childcare and medical advice. Helpful but sometimes assumes more than Eleanor wants; boundary conversations have occurred about visiting frequency. Willing to come stay overnight to help during Eleanor’s medical procedures.

relationships.name: Robert Chan
relationships.description: Lives in another state; calls weekly. Sends care packages for the kids and helps with financial gifts on birthdays. More hands-off due to travel distance.

relationships.name: Tamika Alvarez
relationships.description: Neighbor who has two children of similar ages. Provides reciprocal playdate support, picks up groceries occasionally, and is a confidant for parenting issues. Family meets monthly for a potluck.

relationships.name: Dr. L. Patel
relationships.description: Licensed clinical psychologist who provides weekly CBT and caregiver stress management. Works with Eleanor on cognitive restructuring, pacing, and boundary setting.

relationships.name: Dr. Martinez
relationships.description: Primary pediatrician who is supportive of the family's needs and coordinates with therapists for developmental monitoring. Provides flexible appointment times for late-morning visits.

relationships.name: Sofia (college student)
relationships.description: Trusted sitter who helps several hours per week during medical appointments; reliable and used to working with younger children and families with special needs.

relationships.name: Parenting with Mobility Challenges (local support)
relationships.description: Monthly support group where Eleanor exchanges tips on adaptive gear, accessible playgrounds, and emotional support.

other_facts: Grew up in a mid-sized college town in Ohio as the eldest of three siblings; early responsibilities helped her develop organizational habits.
First memory of helping a younger sibling learn to tie shoes; takes pride in patient teaching moments.
Met Michael in college during a group volunteer tutoring program; they bonded over children's literacy events.
Worked as an early childhood educator for five years before the diagnosis, where she developed skills in curriculum planning and classroom management.
Diagnosis of inflammatory neuropathy began in her early 30s; initial symptoms were dismissed for months before specialized care provided clarity.
She kept a private blog during the first year of diagnosis to process feelings; stopped public posting but maintains a private journal.
Has one small friendly dog (a mixed breed named 'Maple') who is gentle with the children and provides emotional comfort; Maple is not a service dog but is trained for calm behavior around toddlers.
Their suburban home mortgage is manageable but leaves little margin for large unexpected medical expenses; they maintain a modest emergency fund.
Installed a main-floor bedroom for accessibility after the diagnosis—this was a major emotional and financial decision but improved daily functioning.
Has a favorite bench in the local park where she listens to children's audiobooks and sips tea while the kids play nearby.
Is often recognized at the local library for bringing children to story hour and for volunteering to stack books occasionally.
A proud moment: Ava said her first full sentence on a park bench while Eleanor filmed it; she still watches that clip when feeling discouraged.
Fears: losing independence and becoming a burden; uses therapy to reframe these anxieties as interdependence rather than failure.
Regret: not fostering more close friendships before children because parenthood and health limitations made maintaining broad social networks harder.
Financial stressors: periodic co-pays for specialist visits and gaps in coverage for certain adaptive equipment require creative budgeting.
Proudest domestic accomplishment: converting a spare room into a low-shelf, Montessori-style play space that encourages Ava's independence.
Has a long-term plan to create a simple family emergency binder with passwords, medical information, and contact numbers; it's partially complete.
Used to enjoy weekend-long hikes and camping; now prefers short wheelchair-accessible trail walks and family picnics.
Discovered a love for simple woodworking during a home modification project—made a custom low bookshelf for children's books.
Is mildly claustrophobic in crowded elevators; prefers ramps and wide staircases.
Keeps a small 'memory box' for each child with hospital bracelets, first tooth, and handprints; plans to give these to them at age 18.
Has a ritual of Friday 'photo review' where she and Michael select three favorite family photos from the week and print them for the kitchen magnet board.
Once organized a block-wide kid's playdate during the neighborhood association's annual summer fair; it strengthened local connections and accessibility conversations.
Listens to a short gratitude audio before bed each night as part of therapy homework; it helps dampen anxiety loops.
Childcare philosophy: follow the child's lead within safe boundaries—lots of reading, minimal screen time, positive discipline.
Has a small group of four friends who rotate coffee mornings to give each other mini-breaks from parenting.
Enjoys simple seasonal rituals: carving one pumpkin with the children, making hot cocoa with a cinnamon stick in winter, an annual spring trip to the botanical garden.
Is careful about consent: teaches children to ask before hugging others and models asking for consent with caregivers.
Has a favorite comfort recipe—slow-cooker lentil stew—that's easy on bad days and freezes well for future low-energy evenings.
Experienced a near-miss in a parking lot when a driver didn't see her rollator; it resulted in advocacy emails to the city for clearer crosswalk paint near the preschool.
Kept in touch with a former classroom student who now sends occasional drawings; those notes are laminated and kept on the fridge.
Maintains a list of accessible playgrounds and family restrooms in their city and shares it on the local parents' social group.
Was a volunteer story reader at the hospital pediatric ward once; the experience profoundly shaped her belief in small compassionate acts.
Plans to teach her children to prepare a simple meal by age 7, believing practical life skills support independence and confidence.
Has a small collection of children's poetry books she recites from memory when the kids are restless on car trips.
Avoids sugar-heavy birthday parties; organizes nature-themed, low-sugar celebrations with healthy snacks and an outdoor scavenger hunt.
Knows the value of standardized forms: she created a one-page 'childcare instructions' sheet that she leaves with sitters to reduce confusion.
Dream travel memory: hopes to take a low-key beach week with accessible boardwalks and a calm sea for paddle-play, timed when the children are slightly older.
Appreciates small daily rituals: a quiet five minutes of tea after drop-off, a soft lullaby before bed, and sharing a joke with Michael after the kids fall asleep.
